org.jtrim2.utils

Class LazyValues

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jtrim2.utils.LazyValues

  • public final class LazyValues
extends Object
    Defines utility methods to help with lazily initialized values.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static interface  LazyValues.PostCreateAction<T>
      Defines an action to be executed after a lazy object creation.

    • Method Detail

      • lazyNonNullValue

        public static <T> Supplier<T> lazyNonNullValue(Supplier<? extends T> valueFactory)
        Returns a factory caching non-null value returned by the given factory. The value is cached forever.

        Note: Despite caching the value forever, the returned factory does not guarantee that it won't request the value multiple times from the specified factory. That is, the implementation does not hold locks (or wait for other threads) while creating the value. Therefore, it is possible that value gets created multiple times. However, it is guaranteed that every invocation of the get method of the returned factory will return the exact same instance.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the cached value
        Parameters:
        valueFactory - the factory creating the value. This argument cannot be null. The factory may return a null value but null values are not cached, therefore the factory will be called again next time a value is requested if it returns null.
        Returns:
        a factory caching the value returned by the given factory. This method never returns null.
        See Also:
        lazyValueLocked(Supplier)

      • lazyNonNullValue

        public static <T> Supplier<T> lazyNonNullValue(Supplier<? extends T> valueFactory,
                                               LazyValues.PostCreateAction<? super T> postCreateAction)
        Returns a factory caching non-null value returned by the given factory. The value is cached forever.

        An action can be specified what to do with objects after the factory creates them. Warning: There is no guarantee that if the returned Supplier returns an object, the post create action has already been called on that object. The only guarantee is that it will be called eventually. Note however, that since it is guaranteed that the returned provider never returns different objects, the post create action will not be called more than once with its accepted argument true.

        Note: Despite caching the value forever, the returned factory does not guarantee that it won't request the value multiple times from the specified factory. That is, the implementation does not hold locks (or wait for other threads) while creating the value. Therefore, it is possible that value gets created multiple times. However, it is guaranteed that every invocation of the get method of the returned factory will return the exact same instance.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the cached value
        Parameters:
        valueFactory - the factory creating the value. This argument cannot be null. The factory may return a null value but null values are not cached, therefore the factory will be called again next time a value is requested if it returns null.
        postCreateAction - the action to be called after the given factory creates an object. This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        a factory caching the value returned by the given factory. This method never returns null.
        See Also:
        lazyValueLocked(Supplier)

      • lazyNonNullValueEventualInit

        public static <T> Supplier<T> lazyNonNullValueEventualInit(Supplier<? extends T> valueFactory,
                                                           Consumer<? super T> initAction)
        Returns a factory caching non-null value returned by the given factory. The value is cached forever.

        An action can be specified what to do with objects after the factory creates them. Warning: There is no guarantee that if the returned Supplier returns an object, initAction has already been called on that object. The only guarantee is that it will be called eventually. Note however, that since it is guaranteed that the returned provider never returns different objects, initAction will not be called more than once.

        Note: Despite caching the value forever, the returned factory does not guarantee that it won't request the value multiple times from the specified factory. That is, the implementation does not hold locks (or wait for other threads) while creating the value. Therefore, it is possible that value gets created multiple times. However, it is guaranteed that every invocation of the get method of the returned factory will return the exact same instance.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the cached value
        Parameters:
        valueFactory - the factory creating the value. This argument cannot be null. The factory may return a null value but null values are not cached, therefore the factory will be called again next time a value is requested if it returns null.
        initAction - the action to be called after the given factory creates an object which is going to be published. This action is not called for discarded objects. This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        a factory caching the value returned by the given factory. This method never returns null.
        See Also:
        lazyValueLocked(Supplier), lazyNonNullValue(Supplier, PostCreateAction)

      • lazyValue

        public static <T> Supplier<T> lazyValue(Supplier<? extends T> valueFactory)
        Returns a factory caching the value returned by the given factory. The value is cached forever.

        Note: Despite caching the value forever, the returned factory does not guarantee that it won't request the value multiple times from the specified factory. That is, the implementation does not hold locks (or wait for other threads) while creating the value. Therefore, it is possible that value gets created multiple times. However, it is guaranteed that every invocation of the get method of the returned factory will return the exact same instance.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the cached value
        Parameters:
        valueFactory - the factory creating the value. This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        a factory caching the value returned by the given factory. This method never returns null.
        See Also:
        lazyValueLocked(Supplier)

      • lazyValueLocked

        public static <T> Supplier<T> lazyValueLocked(Supplier<? extends T> valueFactory)
        Returns a factory caching the value returned by the given factory. The value is cached forever.

        Unlike lazyValue, the factory returned by this method will never execute the source factory. That is, a lock will be acquired while calling the source factory.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the cached value
        Parameters:
        valueFactory - the factory creating the value. This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        a factory caching the value returned by the given factory. This method never returns null.
        See Also:
        lazyValue(Supplier)
